solution.text:
The square root of 3 more than an unknown number can be written in the form of linear equations as
\(\sqrt {x + 3}\) = _{j}_ ,Where x is the unknown number.
\(\Rightarrow\) \(\sqrt {x + 3}\) = _{j}_
Square on both sides
\(\Rightarrow\) x+3 = _{j}_ \(\times\) _{j}_
\(\Rightarrow\) x = _{{j*j}}_ - 3
\(\Rightarrow\) x = _{{(j**2)-3}}_
Now,when x is added to the new unknown number y, we get the five times of the first unkown number x.
x + y = 2x
Substituting the value of x
_{{(j**2)-3}}_ + y = 5 \(\times\) _{{(j**2)-3}}_
Y = 5 \(\times\) _{{(j**2)-3}}_ - _{{(j**2)-3}}_
Y = 4 \(\times\) _{{(j**2)-3}}_
Y = _{{4*((j**2)-3)}}_

content.text: The square root of 3 more than an unknown number is _{j}_. When that number is added to another unknown number we get the five times of the first unknown number.What is the second unknown number.
